race.name: ALMANZO 100
race.tagline: The Granddaddy of All Gravel Races - where the movement was born, and where your legs go to die on Oriole Road.

vitals.date: May annually (typically first Saturday after Mother's Day)

prestige.explanation: The Almanzo 100 is widely recognized as 'The Granddaddy of All Gravel Races' - the event that helped kickstart the entire movement. Chris Skogen is in the Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame. The Salsa Warbird and Challenge Almanzo tire were literally named after this race. It lacks top-tier series affiliation, but its historical significance and cultural impact are undeniable. Every serious gravel rider knows this name.

race_quality.explanation: This is a grassroots, free event with zero frills - and that's entirely by design. No aid stations, no SAG support, no timing chips in some years. The organizational history has been turbulent with multiple transitions between Chris Skogen, Spring Valley Tourism, and now split between the Heywood Ride and Spring Valley 100. The ethos is admirable ('100% free, 100% self-supported') but organization is basic at best.

experience.explanation: The race experience is authentic and memorable in ways modern commercialized events cannot replicate. Hours of riding through moon-like parallel dimensions without seeing another human. The laid-back vibe. The shared suffering of fresh stone and Oriole Road. The Fight Club rules ('You are on your own x3'). Veterans describe it as transformative, though it lacks the production value and polish of bigger events.

community.explanation: This is where gravel culture was BORN. 'A lot of laid back, beard having, Surly riding, tattoo sporting guys having fun and enjoying each other's company.' The community is passionate, authentic, and welcoming in a way that corporate events simply cannot match. Forum discussions overflow with trip reports and genuine camaraderie. The vibe is legendary and irreplaceable.

field_depth.explanation: Without professional timing, prize money, or series affiliation, the Almanzo doesn't attract top pro fields like major series events. The competition is regional at best - fast locals, dedicated amateurs, and gravel pilgrims. Some strong riders come for the history, but this isn't where you go to race against the best in the world. That's not the point.

value.explanation: FREE. The entry fee is literally zero dollars - always has been, always will be. You register by mailing a postcard. In an era of $200+ race entries, this is almost unheard of. Chris Skogen started the race specifically as a rejection of 'pay-to-play events.' You simply cannot beat the value proposition of a 100-mile race that costs nothing to enter.

expenses.explanation: With free entry, your only costs are travel and lodging. From the Midwest, this is extremely budget-friendly - drive in, stay at a cheap hotel in Rochester or Spring Valley, race for free, drive home. Even from further away, the total trip cost should stay well under $500 for most. The DIY nature keeps everything lean and affordable.

length.explanation: At 100 miles (actually 101), the flagship distance is substantial and puts it firmly in the challenging-but-not-ultra category. The 162-mile Royal and 380-mile Alexander options push into extreme territory for those seeking more punishment.

technicality.explanation: Mixed terrain including well-maintained gravel, freshly laid loose stone, packed dirt, broken pavement, and creek crossings. The second-half transition to energy-sapping fresh stone and the infamous Oriole Road climb at mile 90 (17% grades) add significant technical challenge. Not singletrack extreme, but far from smooth cruising.

elevation.explanation: 6,000-7,000 feet of climbing over 100 miles through the Driftless Region's rolling terrain. The constant ups and downs through bluffs and river valleys accumulate brutally, especially on gravel. Falls just short of the 6,000+ ft threshold for a score of 4, but the relentless nature of Driftless climbing makes every foot count.

climate.explanation: May in Minnesota is weather roulette. Historical conditions have ranged from 30s to 80s Fahrenheit. The infamous 2017 'Hellmanzo' edition brought 40F temperatures, driving rain, high winds, mud blindness, hypothermia cases, and hospital visits. Only 24% finished that year. You might get perfect spring weather or conditions that would make a Viking weep.

altitude.explanation: The Driftless Region sits at relatively low elevation (roughly 800-1,400 feet above sea level). Altitude is not a factor in this race - your legs will suffer from the gravel and climbing, not from thin air.

logistics.explanation: Spring Valley has extremely limited lodging options - essentially one small hotel. Rochester is 19 miles away with more options due to Mayo Clinic, but Minneapolis airport is 2+ hours away. The race embodies DIY spirit - you need to plan your own logistics with no SAG support or aid stations. Not extremely remote, but certainly not convenient either.

adventure.explanation: This is a pilgrimage for gravel purists - the birthplace of modern gravel racing. Riding through the stunning Driftless Region with its towering bluffs, Amish farms, covered bridges, and Forestville/Mystery Cave State Park is genuinely beautiful. The creek crossing at mile 80, the soul-crushing Oriole Road climb, and the pioneer heritage connection to Almanzo Wilder create an epic, memorable experience. Just short of bucket-list status for non-purists.

history.significance: One of the founding events of modern gravel racing in America
history.hall_of_fame: Chris Skogen inducted into Gravel Cycling Hall of Fame
industry_impact: 2012: Salsa released the Warbird - first gravel-specific race bike
history.name_origin: Named after Almanzo Wilder, husband of Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose family farm was near Spring Valley

oriole_road_climb.description: The soul-crusher. Even front-runners often hike-a-bike. 'Resembles a wall' after 90 miles of gravel.

creek_crossing.description: A memorable water crossing that guarantees wet feet regardless of conditions.

second_half_stone.description: Gravel transitions from hard-pack to freshly laid loose stone. Groups ride grass shoulders seeking respite.

incidents: Hospital visits for eye injuries from grit
Riders found holed up in laundromats
Riders blind from mud within 10 miles

lodging.spring_valley: Very limited - Americas Best Value Inn & Suites (~$85/night)
lodging.rochester: Multiple options due to Mayo Clinic presence ($56-120+/night)
lodging.tip: Book early - limited options in Spring Valley

black_pill: The race can break you - 2017 saw only 24% finish rate
Weather is a complete gamble - 30F to 80F conditions have occurred
100% self-supported means if you bonk, flat, or freeze - you are on your own
The course doesn't care about your fitness - fresh stone destroys legs, Oriole Road makes elites walk
The 'Almanzo 100' name is technically retired - now split between Heywood Ride and Spring Valley 100
Organizational history has been turbulent with multiple leadership transitions
Remote location with limited lodging and 2+ hours from major airport
Your bike will suffer - fresh gravel destroys drivetrains, mud clogs everything

meta.notes: Scored as Tier 2 based on iconic status and historical significance, but lacking major series affiliation and professional field depth. The cultural importance and community score would arguably merit Tier 1, but organizational instability and grassroots nature keep it in the established-but-not-premier category.

final_verdict.one_liner: The granddaddy of gravel racing where loose stone and 17% grades separate tourists from riders.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you've got 6+ hours in your legs and can push through loose gravel that feels like riding in sand, this is gravel racing church. The Oriole Road climb at mile 90 will humble anyone undertrained, and the second-half stone layer turns strong groups into survival shuffles. Skip it if you need aid stations or can't handle Minnesota spring weather ranging from hypothermia-inducing rain to scorching sun.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Kanza/Unbound offers similar distance with more prestige but flatter terrain and corporate polish. Ragnarok gives you comparable Midwest suffering with better organization, while Trans Iowa delivers the same self-supported ethos but with fewer riders and more isolation.

course_description.character: The granddaddy of gravel racing rolls through Minnesota's Driftless region where glaciers never flattened the terrain. Six thousand feet of climbing over endless farm roads that transition from hard-pack early to soul-crushing loose stone as you fall apart. The hills never stop coming, and neither does the sensation you're riding through pioneer country on roads that were never meant for bikes.

suffering_zones.label: The Honeymoon Phase
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling farmland on well-maintained gravel roads. You'll think this isn't so bad while burning matches on every roller.

suffering_zones.label: Reality Check Hills
suffering_zones.desc: The Driftless terrain shows its teeth with steeper climbs through river valleys. Your legs start asking questions you can't answer.

suffering_zones.label: The Stone Transition
suffering_zones.desc: Hard-pack gravel becomes freshly laid loose stone that saps watts like quicksand. Groups abandon the road for grass verges, searching for anything rideable.

suffering_zones.label: Creek Crossing Prelude
suffering_zones.desc: A memorable water crossing that's actually a brief respite before the nightmare that awaits ten miles ahead.

suffering_zones.label: Oriole Road Hell
suffering_zones.desc: Seventeen percent grades that turn this into a hike-a-bike for everyone. Even front-runners walk this wall.

course_description.signature_challenge: Oriole Road at mile 90 is the soul-crusher that defines this race. GPS readings hit 17% grades on loose gravel when your legs have nothing left after 6,000 feet of climbing. It doesn't matter how strong you areâ€”this hill breaks everyone.
